full_text: I am glad the Government's focus remains on offshore wind, rather than the more unreliable onshore wind. Increasing the scale of offshore wind production to 50 GW by 2030 and accelerating the deployment of new wind projects will be vital to securing our energy supply.
This strategy says the Government will be doubling the UK's hydrogen production to 10GW by 2030, and ramping up support for the UK's hydrogen economy.  These are good minima to aim for.

The Government's strategy also lacks much in the way of new measures to improve energy efficiency. I believe this is a missed opportunity. Helping people to insulate their homes would reduce energy loss and by extension reduce people's energy bills.

It is encouraging to see the Government commit to building up nuclear power capacity, especially developing Small Modular Reactors. However, the Government should go further and aim to make nuclear a higher proportion of the UK's future energy supply.

I welcome the Government's proposal for a new licensing round for oil and gas this year. But it is critical this happens as soon as possible and the approval process is completed without delay. North Sea oil & gas is vital as we move to a more secure & sustainable energy sector.

The Government has published its Energy Security Strategy here: https://t.co/ympzRARAZi.  

Having read through it, these are my initial thoughts.
The UK has the potential for first mover advantage here. We must grasp the opportunity produced by technological advances to become the world's pre-eminent centre of medical research.
Professor Goldacre's proposals, if enacted properly, will build trust in the health service. And, by facilitating research, they will help us to fight diseases and future pandemics.

Chief among them is the call for the creation of 'Trusted Research Environments' (TREs) - secure analytical environments that allow the use of medical data in research without compromising the privacy of the patients whose data is used.

Professor Ben Goldacre has published his review into using health data for medical research. He has made a number of important recommendations which the government would be wise to implement.
https://t.co/1QXclFW6kd
Talking about these policies is great, but it needs to be backed by swift and decisive government action. I hope to see that later today in the PM’s speech.
Without hydrogen or other energy storage mechanisms, wind power will not be a viable option to base our national strategy on.

There is still further work to be done on enabling us to generate hydrogen reserves using wind and other renewable energy when energy is generated in periods of low national demand and would otherwise go to waste.

Wind power may play an increasingly key role in meeting our energy needs. 

But we should opt for more reliable offshore wind power where possible, and make sure any onshore wind infrastructure is distributed fairly across the country and achieves adequate local support.

The @IPCC_CH said just this week that the use of carbon capture & storage will be necessary to remove unavoidable carbon emissions from the atmosphere.

Tax receipts from North Sea oil & gas can cover the cost of this investment.

Net Zero is not possible without carbon capture.

North Sea oil and gas reserves are a valuable natural resource that we cannot afford to just sit on. North Sea production has the potential to bolster our energy independence. Even more importantly it would raise money to fund carbon capture.
Ideally these small modular reactors would be built by Rolls-Royce. But we need to move fast on this, so if necessary we should use other company's existing technology as well.

A swift and significant expansion of nuclear power ought to be the central pillar of the UK’s energy strategy.  
 
The focus should be on small modular reactors, which are quicker and less expensive to deploy, and can be distributed across the country.

Today the Prime Minister will be outlining the future UK energy strategy.  
 
Getting this strategy right will be vital if we are to meet our Paris Agreement commitments and prevent future energy crises.

Onshore wind turbines produce less energy, on average than offshore due to less wind. 

But if the Government presses on let's see the 20 or so attendees of Cabinet with rural constituencies take at least 3 onshore wind farms each. Why not?

https://t.co/M6952ce5de

Either way, billions will be generated in tax revenue from new extraction. We must use that to roll out carbon capture & storage.

Ukraine isn't fighting so well just because small units are best. The Ukrainian general staff have analysed Russian tactics in Chechnya, Syria, Georgia, Crimea and the Donbas and applied the lessons.

It is true that the European Council has now agreed to a proposed directive allowing lower rates of VAT for solar panels, though it is not yet ratified. Nonetheless, it is good to see the EU finally adopting measures it prevented the UK from introducing years ago.

For instance, the ECJ ruled in 2015 that Britain’s five per cent rate for solar panels contravened EU law. The British Government was then required to change its rate and charge the vast majority of people the full 20 percent.
The Chancellor is right to point out that, because of Brexit, Parliament can choose independently to remove VAT from solar panels and other home energy improvements. https://t.co/5CBqEfyTiA

While the Chancellor has been stressing how hard it is to make tax cuts, the Treasury has forgotten that tax cuts are one of the best routes to growth, as Nigel Lawson demonstrated. And growth is the best protection we have against events such as the COVID-19 crisis.
And the @OBR_UK says it expects real household disposable income to fall at the fastest rate on record - a serious problem that we must keep an eye on. https://t.co/VkerpNytsJ
But there is still more to do. Families are facing a £700 hike to energy bills in just a few days and the measures in today's statement will only partially ease that pain.

It's not just the NICs rise that is worrying working families. Energy, food, and fuel bills are all skyrocketing - hitting the poorest hardest.

That's why I welcome the cut in fuel duty. I'm glad that not only did he listen to my colleagues and I, he also listened to drivers.

It was always very unlikely the Treasury would scrap its NICs plan, no matter how unwise it was.  Now it looks, at least, like his plan will take some pressure off those on the lowest incomes. On the face of it, it should cancel out the increase for the poorest 70%.

To be fair, the Chancellor has delivered more than I was expecting with his Spring Statement

🧵

We should seek to use the money to turn Ukraine into an exemplar for what a free and democratic people can achieve. 

As a result, Ukraine will be on Russia's doorstep as a continuous reminder of what a free, prosperous, and democratic society looks like.

And even a very effective policy of confiscating assets from oligarchs will not reach the numbers concerned.

 So, the democratic world will have to reach into its own pockets to help Ukraine rebuild.

But frankly, even that is not enough. 

Ukraine's economic advisor has already said Russian forces have destroyed $100bn of infrastructure and assets. 

This is going to be rebuilding on a scale never seen before.
After WWII, the Marshall Plan gave billions to West Germany to help it rebuild. In total, it amounted to .54% of the US' GDP at the time. Today, similar support for Ukraine would be $120bn.

The Government is right to start thinking about how we help Ukraine rebuild once the conflict is over. But any money confiscated from oligarchs will not be enough.

Ultimately it is a trade-off between two outcomes - whether we defend the democratic rights of more than 40 million Ukrainians or fail to act now and be forced to act later but at a possible greater cost.

To those who point out that action to support Ukraine will be costly in terms of lives, they are right - the skies over Ukraine will be fought over but if we don’t act now we will need to pay more later.
There are no zero-risk options. If we do not act militarily, then NATO will be significantly weakened and we must fear for the safety of every state that borders Russia.
Everything now is very risky, but that is the price we are paying for ignoring Putin's provocations on at least five occasions over the last 20 years.

If this is confined to the airspace over Ukraine, and is based on a request from President Zelenskyy, this should be perfectly legal under almost any interpretation of international law. It will also reduce the risk of escalation.
It is far too late to get boots on the ground but it is not too late to provide air support to the Ukrainian army which may neutralize Putin's overwhelming armoured superiority.
Therefore if we do not provide military support, more than 40 million Ukrainians will go from living in a democracy to living under a brutal dictatorship.

While we should continue to impose the most ferocious sanctions they are no longer a deterrent. They are a punishment. They will not stop him. 

If NATO does not act now, Ukraine will be defeated in a matter of days.

Whether we like it or not Putin has effectively declared war on the West. 

He will view confining our actions to Article 5 measures as legalistic weakness.

Cygnus was predicated on a situation where the disease was already entrenched, with deaths of up to 400,000 expected. It focussed (badly) on dealing with the consequences of the pandemic, not stopping or preventing it.
